content.webTitle: Morning Mail: Cyclone Pam death toll, NZ X factor judges fired, Coalition policy backdown, #keepitintheground

fields.headline: Morning Mail: Cyclone Pam death toll, NZ X factor judges fired, Coalition policy backdown, #keepitintheground
fields.bodyText: Good morning folks, and welcome to the Morning Mail – sign up here to get it straight to your inbox every weekday morning. Cyclone Pam At least 24 people in Vanuatu have been killed and 3,300 have been displaced by cyclone Pam, the UN has said, with little still known of conditions on the ground in outlying islands. Guardian Australia’s Josh Robertson reports from Port Vila. Vanuatu’s president, Baldwin Lonsdale, describes category five cyclone Pam as ‘a monster that has hit Vanuatu’, wiping out 90% of buildings, and says climate change contributed to the death and destruction. Residents of Vanuatu describe the horror of the storm which battered the island chain over the weekend: I was afraid, I didn’t know if I’d face another day. Follow all our Cyclone Pam coverage here. Keep it in the ground “The argument for a campaign to divest from the world’s most polluting companies is becoming an overwhelming one, on both moral and financial grounds,” writes Guardian editor-in-chief Alan Rusbridger. This is the biggest story in the world. Come behind the scenes as we embark on a global climate change campaign. The challenge? Engage readers in a new way. Join us in asking the Gates Foundation and Wellcome Trust - the world’s two biggest charitable funds - to commit now to divesting from the top 200 fossil fuel companies within five years and to immediately freeze any new investments in those companies. Keep up to date at theguardian.com/keep-it-in-the-ground Australian news and politics University fee deregulation is still facing defeat in Senate despite education minister Christopher Pyne backing down on cuts to research funding . It wasn’t the only backdown from the government yesterday, with Tony Abbott conceding ground on metadata laws with an amendment requiring agencies to get a warrant before accessing journalists’ metadata to identify a source. The controversial asylum bill also faces the prospect of defeat as crossbenchers express qualms about greater powers to reject claims for refugee status. including for failure to produce the correct documents. Abortion will remain a crime in NSW after the state election, with both major parties saying they have no plans to change the law as groups shape up for a post-election battle over a new version of Zoe’s law Tony Abbott’s chief of staff Peta Credlin was described as a “horsewoman of the apocalypse” in damaging leaks from within the Liberal party executive, but First Dog on the Moon is having none of it. Only four horsepersons of the apocalypse? He can easily count well over 40. A study has revealed three-quarters of Muslim Australians feel they are unfairly targeted by terror laws, with most saying terror groups like Isis distort the real meaning of Islam. Around the world Two judges on X Factor NZ have been fired for “bullying” a contestant live on air, likening him to ‘Norman Bates dressing up in his mother’s clothing’. Vladimir Putin, in apparent good health, has been seen in public for the first time since 5 March. “It would be boring without gossip,” the Russian president said after an 11-day absence that launched rumours of ill-health, childbirth or even a palace coup - or it could have just been the flu. “Well, frankly, that’s a little disappointing,” writes Stephen Moss. “President Putin has shown up after an unexplained absence and, as one wag on Twitter said, looks in pretty good shape considering he died on Thursday, fathered a “love child” on Friday and was overthrown in a coup on Saturday.” The BBC’s decision to suspend Jeremy Clarkson and pull the three remaining episodes of Top Gear cost BBC2 nearly 4 million viewers on Sunday night. Victoria Beckham and other celebrities have spoken out in support of Elton John, who was called a “fascist” by designers Dolce & Gabbana after he called for a boycott of their brand in the immediate aftermath of their “synthetic children” comments. One last thing Peta Credlin and the horsepersons of the apocalypse! Seriously? Only four horsepersons of the apocalypse? First Dog easily counts well over 40. Have an excellent day – and if you spot something I’ve missed, let me know in the comments here or on Twitter @earleyedition.
